We have 11 new PhD students from all over the world. Read More         Facilities & Resources   Freedom Evo 150   The Freedom Evo Robot facilitates high-throughput experiments. Read More             News             The Searle Scholars Program supports research of outstanding individuals who have recently begun their appointment at the assistant professor level. Each year 15 new individuals are named Searle Scholars and awarded flexible grants of $300,000 over three years.   Read More               In Nature Biotechnology, Satija et al. describe the Seurat algorithm to infer the spatial localization of single cells during Zebrafish embryogenesis based on RNA-seq data.   Read More               Christiaen Lab published a review in Nature on development and evolution of the heart and head muscles.   Read More               In collaboration with scientists at Lisbon University and Emory, the Eichenberger lab reports the functional characterization of an anti-sigma factor regulating canalization of gene expression during sporulation in Bacillus subtilis,   Read More               Kaplan, Razy-Krajka and Christiaen published a new review on heart and head muscles development and evolution in Current Opinion in Genes and Development, titled “Regulation and evolution of cardiopharyngeal cell identity and behavior: insights from simple chordates”.   Read More               Duncan Smith has been named a 2015 Searle Scholar       Satija publishes algorithm for spatially mapping single cell RNA       Christiaen Lab published a review in Nature       Eichenberger lab publishes a paper in PLoS Genetics       Christiaen Lab published a new review in Current Opinion         See all News         People Past and Present   Stephen J. Small   Professor   "Studying the molecules that transform fertilized eggs into complex animals that can fly."             Meet Dr.         Small         Video Spotlight Kris Gunsalus talks about her latest Cell paper on gene networks in a complex tissue   High-content screening for gene profiling has generally been limited to single cells. Here, we explore an alternative approach—profiling gene function by analyzing effects of gene knockdowns on the architecture of a complex tissue in a multicellular organism. Read More                 Contact Us | © New York University , Arts and Science

Meet Dr.         Small         Video Spotlight Kris Gunsalus talks about her latest Cell paper on gene networks in a complex tissue   High-content screening for gene profiling has generally been limited to single cells. Foundations of Science 3 & 4 Lab - NYU Libraries                               This is the "Foundations of Science 3 & 4 Lab" guide.      Alternate Page for Screenreader Users      Skip to Page Content                                             Foundations of Science 3 & 4 Lab A collection of resources, including summary articles and video tutorials, for students in this course.        Last update: Oct 1, 2013        URL: http://guides.nyu.edu/content_mobile.php?pid=285172                                                                          Home                                                                                  Do you have more questions?                   Photo credit    NYUAD Librarians are available to answer your questions via chat, email or in person at the Information Desk.            Comments (0)                                         Welcome!                 Welcome to the library guide for Foundations of Science 3 & 4 Lab! In this guide, you will find:     Introductory articles explaining basic concepts   Video & Interactive Tutorials   News articles that deal with the concepts you will be covering in this course     If you have any questions, please email us or stop by the library.             Comments (0)                                         Supplemental Material from Your Textbooks                 Did you know you can access extra material including demos, lectures, practice exercises and quizzes related to the subjects covered in your textbooks? Check out the following links to learn more!          Matter & Interactions                   Chemistry (Zumdahl)                   Biology (Brooker)                    Comments (0)                                         Science Librarian                   Amani Magid  JavaScript disabled or chat unavailable.   Chat is offline.  Contact Info NYUAD Library Send Email  Links: Profile & Guides Subjects: Biology , Chemistry , Computer Science , Engineering , Physics , Psychology             Comments (0)                                              close                                                                                                          Precipitation, Absorption, & Bohr Model                                                                                  Absorption                  Absorbance Spectrum A tutorial that describes absorbance spectrum and includes examples of experiments. Spectrophotometry Basic principles of spectrophotometry. Lights and Lasers Invade the Clinic A news article that describes new optical techniques that use spectroscopy. The Amateur Scientist Article about using the concept of Beer's Law to construct and use a photoelectric colorimeter. Spectrophotometry Introduction A video tutorial about the concepts of spectrophotometry, transmittance, absorbance and the Beer-Lambert Law. Spectrophotometry Example Video tutorial about determining concentration based on absorbance.            Comments (0)                                         Precipitation                  Precipitation Reactions Video of an experiment that examines precipitation reactions. Precipitation- Summary Summary article that explains the concept of precipitation. Risky Precipitate News article about hazardous precipitates. Water, Wine, Milk, or Beer? Article that describes a simple experiment involving precipitates.            Comments (0)                                         Bohr Model                  Bohr Model (Emission) Animated explanation of the concept of atomic emission. Bohr Model- Summary Summary article that explains the Bohr Model. Bohr Model Tutorial Interactive tutorial that explains the concept of the Bohr Model.            Comments (0)                                              close                                                                                                          Thermochemistry & Le Chatelier                                                                                  Thermochemistry                  Hess's Law and Reaction Enthalpy Change A video tutorial that describes using Hess's Law and standard heats of formation to determine the enthalpy change for reactions. Two Multipurpose Thermochemical Experiments for General Chemistry Article describes two experiments that examine thermochemical principles. Teaching Hess's Law Lists tips for mastering the concept of Hess's Law based on a set of simple rules. Hess's Law Example A video tutorial examining Hess's Law.            Comments (0)                                         Le Chatelier                  Le Chatelier's Principle A video tutorial that explains Le Chatelier's Principle regarding the "stressing" of reactions in equilibrium. Le Châtelier's Principle, Temperature Effects, and Entropy Article summary: A useful extension of Le Châtelier's Principle to predict concentration, pressure, and temperature effects solely from the equation for the net reaction.            Comments (0)                                              close                                                                                                          Buffers                                                                                  Buffers                  Buffers & Hendersen-Hasselbalch A video explaining buffers and the Hendersen-Hasselbalch equation Titration Roundup A video that explains titration curves. Buffers Tutorial A video tutorial that describes the concepts surrounding buffers. Titrations Tutorials Tutorials about titration topics. Includes examples of experiments and review questions. Buffers- Summary Summary article that describes the concept of buffers.            Comments (0)                                              close                                                                                                          Crystal Project                                                                                  Crystals                          Crystals Guide- more information!                   Gels in Crystalization of Biological Macromolecules                   Teaching Protein Crystallization by the Gel Acupuncture Method                   The Wonderful World of Crystals Lecture                    Comments (0)                                         Books about Crystals                 Search SpringerLink , ebrary and our online catalog to find books like these:   Crystals and Crystal Growing - Alan Holden Call Number: QD921 .H58 1982   Crystal Growth Technology - B. Byrappa Available online!   Crystals: Growth, Morphology, and Perfection - Ichiro Sunagawa Call Number: QD921 .S85 2005 Also available online!   Morphology of Crystals - Ichirō Sunagawa Call Number: QD921 .M758 1987   Springer Handbook of Crystal Growth - Dhanaraj & Byrappa Available online!   Structure and Properties of Liquid Crystals - Lev M. Blinov Call Number: QD923 .B56 2010   Structure and Chemistry of Crystalline Solids - Bodie Eugene Douglas Available online!   Science and Technology of Crystal Growth - J. P. Van der Eerden Available online!   Advances in Crystal Growth Inhibition Technologies - Zahid Amjad Available online!            Comments (0)                                              close                                                                                                          Citing Your Sources                                                                                  Citing Sources in APA style and Managing References                   The boxes below give citation examples for common formats in APA style : print and electronic .    View the Basics of APA Style tutorial: http://flash1r.apa.org/apastyle/basics/index.htm   For more information, the Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association, 6th edition, is available in the NYUAD Library at call number BF76.7 .P83 2010. A supplement, APA Style Guide to Electronic Sources , is linked here, available for download by NYUAD students, faculty, staff only. Corrections to the 6th edition are linked here .   See here for information about EndNote and other bibliographic management software.             Comments (0)                                         Citing PRINT Sources, APA                  For examples not listed here, see print version of the Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association , 6th ed, at call number BF76.7.P83 2010.             Reference Type     In Reference List   In-Text Citation        Book: 1 Author        Batavia , M. (2006). Contraindications in physical rehabilitation: Doing no harm . St. Louis , MO : Saunders Elsevier.        (Batavia, 2006)       Book: 3 to 6 Authors          Hoskins, C. N., Haber, J., & Budin, W. C. (2001). Breast cancer: Journey to recovery . New York : Springer Publishing Company.       (Hoskins, Haber, & Budin, 2001) first citation   (Hoskins et al., 2001) subsequent citations         Book: Editor, Translator, or Compiler (instead of author)        Mezey, M. D. (Ed.). (2001). The encyclopedia of elder care: The comprehensive resource on geriatric and social care . New York : Springer Publishing Company.        (Mezey, 2001)       Book: Chapter, Introduction, Preface, Foreword, Afterword, Encyclopedia Entry        Mitty, E. L. (2001). Assisted living. In M. D. (Mitty, 2001)       Journal Article: 1 Author      Rosenfeld, P. (2005). (Rosenfeld, 2005)       Journal Article: 2 Authors      Collard, S., & Tempelman-Kluit, N. (2006). The other way in: Goal-based library content through CMS. Supplement, APA Style Guide to Electronic References , is available for download by NYUAD students, faculty, and staff by clicking the link. Contact the NYUAD Library via email or consult the EndNote LibGuide .           Comments (0)                                         Using Cite While You Write                 EndNote's Cite While You Write (CWYW) feature inserts EndNote commands into Micosoft Word. Use CWYW tools to create footnotes, in-text references and bibliographies from your EndNote Library. Watch an online tutorial on CWYW here .              Comments (0)                                         What Is EndNote?                 EndNote is a desktop software for managing bibliographic citations. Using EndNote, you can transfer references from online research databases into EndNote and create bibliographies.   Download EndNote HERE . EndNote X5 is available for PC and EndNote X4 is available for Mac OS 10.4+. (There is no Unix version).   *Note for PC users: Make sure you unzip the file before running the installer, otherwise you will be prompted for a product key.           Comments (0)                                         What is EndNote Web?                 NYU also subscribes to EndNote Web. You don't have to run EndNote on your desktop to use EndNote Web. You can export citations to EndNote Web and download them later to EndNote on your desktop, or create bibliographies directly from EndNote Web.   Gettting an Account     Go to MyEndNoteWeb.com   Sign up using your NYU email address.       To transfer references from EndNote Desktop to EndNote Web:     On your EndNote Desktop, go to Edit | Preferences and choose EndNote Web. Enter your EndNote Web username and password.   Go to Tools | EndNote Web. A box will open asking you whether you want to transfer references TO or FROM EndNote Web.   If you do not want to export (copy) all your references to Desktop EndNote, you should organize them in Groups.
